payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).

Thanks!

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.

- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).

Thanks!

%define STAGE2_BASE   0x0000000000010000
%define STACK_TOP     0x0000000000090000
; Place paging structures safely above the stage2 image (~0x70xxx)
; Use 1 MiB region to avoid overlap with loaded kernel image and BSS.
%define PML4          0x0000000000100000
%define PDP           0x0000000000101000
%define PD0           0x0000000000102000
%define PD1           0x0000000000103000
%define PD2           0x0000000000104000
%define PD3           0x0000000000105000

%define CODE32_SEL 0x08
%define DATA32_SEL 0x10
%define CODE64_SEL 0x18
%define TSS_SEL   0x20

%define TSS_RSP0_OFFSET 4
%define TSS_IOMAP_OFFSET 0x66
%define COM1 0x3F8

BITS 16

section .start16
  global start16
  extern kernel_main
  extern __bss_start
  extern __bss_end
  extern serial_write_char

start16:
  cli
  mov ax, 0x1000
  mov ds, ax
  mov es, ax
  mov ax, 0x9000           ; place real-mode stack well above stage2 image
  mov ss, ax
  mov sp, 0xFFFC

  ; BIOS serial init (COM1, 9600 8N1) and banner
  mov dx, 0
  mov ah, 0x00
  mov al, 0xE3
  int 0x14
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, 'S'
  int 0x14
  mov al, ':'
  int 0x14
  ; and VGA BIOS marker
  mov ah, 0x0E
  mov al, 's'
  mov bh, 0x00
  mov bl, 0x07
  int 0x10

  ; (E820 memory map collection removed for bring-up simplicity)

  ; Enable A20 using port 0x92
  in   al, 0x92
  or   al, 0x02
  out  0x92, al

  ; Load our GDT descriptor without needing high addresses
  call .get_gdt_ptr
.get_gdt_ptr:
  pop si
  add si, gdt_ptr - .get_gdt_ptr
  lgdt [si]

  ; Print 'P' BEFORE setting PE to avoid BIOS INT in protected mode
  mov dx, 0
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, 'P'
  int 0x14

  ; Enter protected mode
  mov eax, cr0
  or  eax, 0x1
  mov cr0, eax

  ; Far jump with 32-bit operand to flush prefetch / load CS
  o32 jmp CODE32_SEL:pmode_entry

  ALIGN 8
gdt:
  dq 0
  dq 0x00CF9A000000FFFF      ; 32-bit code
  dq 0x00CF92000000FFFF      ; 32-bit data
  dq 0x00A09A0000000000      ; 64-bit code
tss_descriptor:
  dq 0
  dq 0
gdt_end:

gdt_ptr:
  dw gdt_end - gdt - 1
  dq gdt

; (E820 memory map collection removed)

ALIGN 16
tss64:
  dd 0
  dd 0
  dq 0                ; rsp0
  dq 0                ; rsp1
  dq 0                ; rsp2
  dq 0                ; reserved1
  dq 0                ; ist1
  dq 0                ; ist2
  dq 0                ; ist3
  dq 0                ; ist4
  dq 0                ; ist5
  dq 0                ; ist6
  dq 0                ; ist7
  dq 0                ; reserved2
  dw 0                ; reserved3
  dw 0                ; iomap base (set later)
tss64_end:

section .pmode
BITS 32
pmode_entry:
  mov ax, DATA32_SEL
  mov ds, ax
  mov es, ax
  mov ss, ax
  mov esp, 0x90000

  ; Initialize COM1 quickly in I/O mode (115200 8N1)
  mov dx, COM1+1
  xor al, al
  out dx, al           ; disable interrupts
  mov dx, COM1+3
  mov al, 0x80
  out dx, al           ; DLAB on
  mov dx, COM1+0
  mov al, 0x01         ; divisor low (115200)
  out dx, al
  mov dx, COM1+1
  xor al, al           ; divisor high
  out dx, al
  mov dx, COM1+3
  mov al, 0x03         ; 8N1, DLAB off
  out dx, al
  mov dx, COM1+2
  mov al, 0xC7         ; FIFO enable/clear
  out dx, al
  mov dx, COM1+4
  mov al, 0x0B         ; OUT2=1
  out dx, al

  ; emit 'p' in pmode
  mov dx, COM1+5
.pm_wait:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .pm_wait
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'p'
  out dx, al

  ; Build paging structures for 2 MiB identity map
  cld
  xor eax, eax

  mov edi, PML4
  mov ecx, 4096/4

  mov edi, PDP

  mov dword [PDP  + (0*8) + 4], 0

  mov dword [PDP  + (1*8) + 0], PD1 | 0x3

.map_low_loop:

.map_high_loop:

  mov [edi + 0], edx

  add edi, 8

.map_high3_loop:

  mov [edi + 0], edx
  mov dword [edi + 4], 0
  add eax, 0x00200000
  add edi, 8
  loop .map_high3_loop

  mov eax, cr4
  or  eax, (1 << 5)          ; enable PAE
  mov cr4, eax

  mov eax, PML4
  mov cr3, eax

  mov ecx, 0xC0000080        ; EFER

section .longmode
BITS 64
default rel
long_entry:
  mov ax, DATA32_SEL
  mov ds, ax
  mov es, ax
  mov ss, ax
  mov rsp, STACK_TOP

  ; emit 'L' in long mode
  mov dx, COM1+5
.lm_wait:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .lm_wait
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'L'
  out dx, al

  lea rdi, [rel tss64]
  mov rbx, STACK_TOP
  mov qword [rdi + TSS_RSP0_OFFSET], rbx
  mov word  [rdi + TSS_IOMAP_OFFSET], (tss64_end - tss64)

  lea rcx, [rel tss_descriptor]
  mov edx, (tss64_end - tss64 - 1)
  mov word [rcx], dx
  mov rax, rdi
  mov word [rcx + 2], ax
  shr rax, 16
  mov byte [rcx + 4], al
  mov byte [rcx + 5], 0x89          ; 64-bit available TSS
  mov eax, edx
  shr eax, 16
  and eax, 0x0F
  mov byte [rcx + 6], al
  mov rax, rdi
  shr rax, 24
  mov byte [rcx + 7], al
  mov rax, rdi
  shr rax, 32
  mov dword [rcx + 8], eax
  mov dword [rcx + 12], 0

  mov ax, TSS_SEL
  ltr ax

  ; Debug markers around BSS clear: 'c' (before), 'd' (after size calc), 'e' (after clear)
  mov dx, COM1+5
.lm_dbg1:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .lm_dbg1
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'c'
  out dx, al

  ; Zero .bss so C code starts with clean globals.
  ; Use absolute addresses rather than RIP-relative LEA math for clarity.
  cld
  mov rdi, __bss_start
  mov rcx, __bss_end
  sub rcx, rdi

  ; emit 'd' after computing rcx
  mov dx, COM1+5
.lm_dbg2:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .lm_dbg2
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'd'
  out dx, al

  xor eax, eax
  rep stosb

  ; emit 'e' after clear
  mov dx, COM1+5
.lm_dbg3:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .lm_dbg3
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'e'
  out dx, al

  ; emit 'B' after bss clear
  mov dx, COM1+5
.lm2_wait:
  in al, dx
  test al, 0x20
  jz .lm2_wait
  mov dx, COM1
  mov al, 'B'
  out dx, al

  call kernel_main

halt_loop:
  hlt
  jmp halt_loop

; Assembled with: nasm -f bin -o boot.bin boot.asm

%ifndef STAGE2_SEG
%define STAGE2_SEG     0x1000        ; load segment for stage2 (phys 0x10000)
%endif
%ifndef STAGE2_OFF
%define STAGE2_OFF     0x0000
%endif
%ifndef STAGE2_LBA
%define STAGE2_LBA     1             ; start right after boot sector
%endif
%ifndef STAGE2_SECTORS
%define STAGE2_SECTORS 128           ; placeholder, overridden by build
%endif

BITS 16
ORG 0x7C00

start:
  cli
  xor ax, ax
  mov ds, ax
  mov es, ax
  mov ss, ax
  mov sp, 0x7C00
  sub sp, 0x0200            ; move stack below code/data to avoid clobber

  mov [boot_drive], dl     ; BIOS passes boot drive in DL

  ; --- Quick serial init via BIOS (COM1, 9600 8N1) and banner ---
  mov dx, 0                 ; COM1
  mov ah, 0x00
  mov al, 0xE3              ; 9600 baud, 8N1
  int 0x14
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, 'B'
  int 0x14
  mov al, ':'
  int 0x14
  ; Also drop a marker to VGA text via BIOS
  mov ah, 0x0E
  mov al, 'b'
  mov bh, 0x00
  mov bl, 0x07
  int 0x10

  ; --- Enable A20 (fast 0x92 gate) ---
  in   al, 0x92
  or   al, 0x02
  out  0x92, al

  ; --- Load stage2 via INT 13h extensions (AH=42h), chunked reads ---
  mov   bx, STAGE2_SEG       ; BX holds current destination segment
  mov   ax, STAGE2_SECTORS
  mov   [remain_secs], ax    ; remaining sectors in memory (avoid clobber)
  mov   di, dap              ; DI -> DAP
  mov   byte [di + 0], 0x10  ; DAP size
  mov   byte [di + 1], 0x00  ; DAP reserved
  mov   word [di + 4], STAGE2_OFF
  mov   word [di + 6], bx
  mov   dword [di + 8], STAGE2_LBA
  mov   dword [di + 12], 0

.read_loop:
  mov   ax, [remain_secs]
  cmp   ax, 0
  je    .read_done
  cmp   ax, 127
  jbe   .count_ok
  mov   ax, 127
.count_ok:
  mov   [di + 2], ax         ; DAP sector count

  ; call BIOS to read this chunk
  mov   si, dap
  mov   dl, [boot_drive]
  mov   ah, 0x42
  int   0x13
  jc    disk_error

  ; emit a dot over serial per chunk
  push dx                  ; preserve remaining-sectors counter
  mov dx, 0               ; COM1 for BIOS INT 14h
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, '.'
  int 0x14
  pop dx

  ; advance LBA: lba += count (add to 32-bit little endian at [dap+8])
  mov   cx, [di + 2]
  add   word [di + 8], cx
  adc   word [di + 10], 0

  ; advance destination segment by count * 32 paragraphs (512B)
  mov   ax, cx
  shl   ax, 5
  add   [di + 6], ax

  ; remaining -= count
  sub   [remain_secs], cx
  jmp   .read_loop

.read_done:
  ; newline at the end
  mov dx, 0
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, 0x0D
  int 0x14
  mov al, 0x0A
  int 0x14

  ; Jump to loaded stage2 (real mode)
  ; print 'J' to serial just before jump
  mov dx, 0
  mov ah, 0x01
  mov al, 'J'
  int 0x14
  jmp   STAGE2_SEG:STAGE2_OFF

; --- Data ---
boot_drive: db 0

; Put the error string *before* the error routine to avoid forward-ref issues
err_msg db 'Disk read error',0

; Disk Address Packet (DAP) â€” 16 bytes (aligning to be tidy)
ALIGN 16

dap:
  db 0x10               ; size
  db 0x00               ; reserved
  dw STAGE2_SECTORS     ; sectors to read
  dw STAGE2_OFF         ; dest offset
  dw STAGE2_SEG         ; dest segment
  dd STAGE2_LBA         ; LBA low
  dd 0x00000000         ; LBA high

remain_secs: dw 0

; --- Simple error print loop (no dotted local labels) ---

disk_error:
  mov si, err_msg
.de_print:
  lodsb
  test al, al
  jz   short .de_halt
  mov ah, 0x0E
  mov bh, 0x00
  mov bl, 0x07
  int 0x10
  jmp  short .de_print
.de_halt:
  hlt
  jmp  short .de_halt

; Boot signature *must* be the last two bytes of the 512â€‘byte sector
TIMES 510-($-$$) db 0
DW 0xAA55

{"output":"NASM     := nasm
CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64
HOST_CC  ?= cc

SRC_DIR     := src
ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
ATK_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/atk
NET_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/net
SBIN_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/sbin
INCLUDE_DIR := include
OBJDIR      := build

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) \
          -fno-merge-constants

BOOT_SRC    := $(ARCH_DIR)/boot.asm
STAGE2_SRC  := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.asm
STAGE2_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.ld

C_SOURCES := \
	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(NET_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(SBIN_DIR)/*.c)

C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))

STAGE2_OBJ := $(OBJDIR)/arch/x86/stage2.o
STAGE2_OBJS := $(STAGE2_OBJ) $(C_OBJECTS)

BOOT_BIN   := $(OBJDIR)/boot.bin
STAGE2_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.elf
STAGE2_BIN := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.bin

all: os.img

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(STAGE2_OBJ): $(STAGE2_SRC)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(NASM) -f elf64 -o $@ $<

$(BOOT_BIN): $(BOOT_SRC) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	stsz=$$(wc -c < $(STAGE2_BIN)); \
	secs=$$(( ($$stsz + 511) / 512 )); \
	echo "Assembling boot sector with STAGE2_SECTORS=$$secs"; \
	$(NASM) -f bin -o $@ -D STAGE2_SECTORS=$$secs $<

$(STAGE2_ELF): $(STAGE2_OBJS) $(STAGE2_LD)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(STAGE2_LD) -o $@ $(STAGE2_OBJS)

$(STAGE2_BIN): $(STAGE2_ELF)
	$(OBJCOPY) -O binary $< $@

# 1.44MB **floppy/drive** image (NOT an ISO/CD)
os.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	@# Create a 1.44MB floppy image
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=512 count=2880 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

# Optional: small HDD-style image (no partition table, boots from LBA0 directly)
hdd.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=1M count=16 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

QEMU_DEBUG_LOG   ?= qemu-debug.log
QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS ?= -d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors -D $(QEMU_DEBUG_LOG)
HOMEBREW_PREFIX  := $(shell brew --prefix)

# --- choose networking backend: user (slirp), vmnet-shared (NAT), vmnet-bridged (bridge en0)
NET_BACKEND ?= vmnet-shared

# Packet capture (works for all backends)
NETDUMP := -object filter-dump,id=n0dump,netdev=n0,queue=all,file=qemu-net.pcap

# Backend-specific NETDEV flags
NETDEV_user := -netdev user,id=n0,net=10.0.2.0/24,dhcpstart=10.0.2.15

# Defaults
QEMU_NET_PREFIX :=
NETDEV := $(NETDEV_user)

# vmnet-shared via socket_vmnet (rootless): wrap QEMU and use fd=3
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-shared)
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# vmnet-bridged via socket_vmnet (rootless): choose interface with VMNET_BRIDGE=en0/en1/...
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-bridged)
  VMNET_BRIDGE ?= en0
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet.bridged.$(VMNET_BRIDGE)
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# Device (keep RTL8139 + MAC)
NIC := -device rtl8139,netdev=n0,mac=52:54:00:12:34:56

run: os.img
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -fda os.img -boot a -no-reboot -monitor none -serial stdio \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

run-hdd: hdd.img
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -drive file=hdd.img,format=raw,if=ide -no-reboot -monitor none -serial stdio \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

clean:
	rm -rf $(OBJDIR) os.img hdd.img

tests/dhcp_packet_test: tests/dhcp_packet_test.c
	$(HOST_CC) -std=c11 -Wall -Wextra -Werror -o $@ $<

test-dhcp: tests/dhcp_packet_test
	./tests/dhcp_packet_test

.PHONY: all run run-hdd clean test-dhcp

**Summarizing implementation and next steps**

Iâ€™m putting together a clear summary with Implementation and Next Steps sections. The Implementation bullets will cover the stage2 heap region changes, new heap headers, the allocator code, kernel integration with CLI command including shell command array updates, plus confirming a successful build with `make`. Then the Next Steps will suggest booting with `make run-hdd` and running the new CLI command to verify heap allocation. payload.message:
**Implementation**
- Stage2 reserves a dedicated 16â€¯MiB heap window at 0x02000000 and exports its bounds for C code (`src/arch/x86/stage2.asm:3`, `src/arch/x86/stage2.asm:383`), keeping it well above the VFS/video buffers.
- Published the heap API so other code can call it (`include/heap.h:6`, `include/libc.h:14`) without pulling in extra headers.
- Built a first-fit allocator with 16-byte alignment, block splitting/coalescing, and overflow-safe calloc/realloc paths that rely on the stage2-provided region (`src/kernel/heap.c:6`).
- Kernel now brings the heap online before subsystem init, and the shell exposes an `alloc1m` command that reports each 1â€¯MiB allocationâ€™s address (`src/kernel/kernel.c:20`, `src/sbin/shell.c:81`, `include/shell_commands.h:9`, `src/sbin/cmd_alloc1m.c:29`).
- Verified the tree still builds by running `make`.

**Next Steps**
- Boot with `make run-hdd`, run `alloc1m` a few times, and confirm the printed addresses sit above the existing static pools and keep advancing as expected.

payload.text:
**Designing dynamic linked list structure**

I'm planning a new linked list system to replace static arrays for windows and buttons, switching to dynamic allocation with malloc. I want to create a general `atk_list_t` with nodes that hold void pointers, enabling flexible storage and easy iteration in both directions. To maintain existing semantics like indexing and layering order, functions to push, remove, and get nodes by index will be essential, plus adapting state fields to use pointers instead of indexes for cleaner referencing. This approach aims to remove size limits and make widget management more dynamic and scalable.

payload.text:
**Summarizing key code changes with instructions**

I'm putting together a clear summary of the main modifications, referencing important files with line numbers and describing the shift to dynamic lists and pointer-based management of widgets and windows. I'll include notes about the successful `make` run and suggest next steps like running `make run-hdd` to verify everything works smoothly.

payload.message:
**Highlights**
- Introduced a lightweight doubly linked list utility to back dynamic widget storage (`include/atk/atk_list.h:1`, `src/atk/atk_list.c:7`), removing the old fixed-size pools.
- Added heap-friendly widget constructors/destructors (`include/atk/object.h:40`, `src/atk/atk_object.c:33`) so windows/buttons can be allocated and freed with the kernel heap.
- Reworked ATK state/priv structs to carry list nodes and direct widget pointers instead of counts (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:24`) and taught button configuration to reset its list hook (`src/atk/atk_button.c:17`).
- Window management now allocates per-instance storage, tracks children in lists, and frees everything on close (`src/atk/atk_window.c:206`, `src/atk/atk_window.c:529`), eliminating hard limits.
- Desktop icons follow the same pattern: dynamic allocation, list-backed draw/hit-test, and safe teardown (`src/atk/atk_desktop.c:42`, `src/atk/atk_desktop.c:116`).
- Mouse routing is pointer-based and iterates the new lists, so stacking/dragging logic no longer depends on array indices (`src/atk/atk.c:62`).

- Built the tree with `make`.

**Next Steps**
1. Boot with `make run-hdd`, open several windows, and drag/close them to confirm layering and cleanup still behave without the old limits.
2. Use `alloc1m`/`free` from the CLI while playing with ATK widgets to ensure the heap-backed allocations coexist cleanly.

content.text:
**Highlights**
- Introduced a lightweight doubly linked list utility to back dynamic widget storage (`include/atk/atk_list.h:1`, `src/atk/atk_list.c:7`), removing the old fixed-size pools.
- Added heap-friendly widget constructors/destructors (`include/atk/object.h:40`, `src/atk/atk_object.c:33`) so windows/buttons can be allocated and freed with the kernel heap.
- Reworked ATK state/priv structs to carry list nodes and direct widget pointers instead of counts (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:24`) and taught button configuration to reset its list hook (`src/atk/atk_button.c:17`).
- Window management now allocates per-instance storage, tracks children in lists, and frees everything on close (`src/atk/atk_window.c:206`, `src/atk/atk_window.c:529`), eliminating hard limits.
- Desktop icons follow the same pattern: dynamic allocation, list-backed draw/hit-test, and safe teardown (`src/atk/atk_desktop.c:42`, `src/atk/atk_desktop.c:116`).
- Mouse routing is pointer-based and iterates the new lists, so stacking/dragging logic no longer depends on array indices (`src/atk/atk.c:62`).

- Built the tree with `make`.

This involves modifying shell_output_t to manage console, file, or buffer targets, updating initialization and write functions, and adjusting shell command handlers to return strings so the text shell can print them afterward. Iâ€™m also thinking through how to handle redirects and serial output consistently in this new model. There is a lot here!

payload.text:
**Designing text input and label widgets**

I'm planning to extend keyboard handling by adding a key event processor integrated into the video loop. To support text input, I'll design new label and text input widgets with dynamic text management, multi-line support, and basic caret handling. Managing these widgets will involve updating window structures to hold generic child widgets alongside buttons, adjusting drawing routines to render all children, and implementing focus and hit testing for input. This also involves creating new widget modules and carefully structuring event dispatch and rendering to smoothly incorporate text input into the existing UI framework.

**Refactoring shell error handling**

I'm updating error reporting so commands return error messages as strings instead of printing directly. This means replacing `shell_print_error` calls with writing errors to the commandâ€™s output buffer, ensuring consistent handling across commands and fitting the new shell execution model. I'll audit commands like `cmd_start_video` and others to apply this change.

summary.text:
**Designing text input and label widgets**

I'm planning to extend keyboard handling by adding a key event processor integrated into the video loop. To support text input, I'll design new label and text input widgets with dynamic text management, multi-line support, and basic caret handling. Managing these widgets will involve updating window structures to hold generic child widgets alongside buttons, adjusting drawing routines to render all children, and implementing focus and hit testing for input. This also involves creating new widget modules and carefully structuring event dispatch and rendering to smoothly incorporate text input into the existing UI framework.

**Refactoring shell error handling**

I'm updating error reporting so commands return error messages as strings instead of printing directly. This means replacing `shell_print_error` calls with writing errors to the commandâ€™s output buffer, ensuring consistent handling across commands and fitting the new shell execution model. I'll audit commands like `cmd_start_video` and others to apply this change.

payload.text:
**Designing shell output and ATK input widgets**

I'm planning a major refactor to capture shell output into buffers or files, replacing direct error printing with string returns via a new shell_output interface. This involves creating helpers like shell_output_error, updating commands to write to shell_output instead of printing directly, implementing shell_execute_line to run commands capturing output or redirecting, and then proceeding to add ATK GUI elements like labels and text inputs with appropriate focus, drawing, and text handling. It's a big step-by-step overhaul touching key modules and command handling for better integration and flexibility.

**Extending ATK with text input focus and shell integration**

I'm working on adding text input focus management, hit testing, and key handling within the ATK GUI system by maintaining lists of text inputs per window and updating mouse interaction to set focus properly. Alongside this, I'm designing a shell window widget that includes a label and input field, handling command submission and interaction via the shell state, while managing lifetime and cleanup through window context callbacks for smooth integration.

**Implementing text input submission and shell window commands**

Iâ€™m adding full handling for text input submission, including insert/backspace/newline processing, and hooking the submit handler to update the shell window label with command output. Iâ€™m also wiring the new shell window creation into the desktop UI with its own icon and managing focus cleanly on window close, while preparing to update shell command output handling step-by-step.

summary.text:
**Designing shell output and ATK input widgets**

I'm planning a major refactor to capture shell output into buffers or files, replacing direct error printing with string returns via a new shell_output interface. This involves creating helpers like shell_output_error, updating commands to write to shell_output instead of printing directly, implementing shell_execute_line to run commands capturing output or redirecting, and then proceeding to add ATK GUI elements like labels and text inputs with appropriate focus, drawing, and text handling. It's a big step-by-step overhaul touching key modules and command handling for better integration and flexibility.

Alongside this, I'm designing a shell window widget that includes a label and input field, handling command submission and interaction via the shell state, while managing lifetime and cleanup through window context callbacks for smooth integration.

**Implementing text input submission and shell window commands**

Iâ€™m adding full handling for text input submission, including insert/backspace/newline processing, and hooking the submit handler to update the shell window label with command output. Iâ€™m also wiring the new shell window creation into the desktop UI with its own icon and managing focus cleanly on window close, while preparing to update shell command output handling step-by-step.

payload.text:
**Summarizing key shell and UI updates**

I'll highlight the major enhancements like the new shell output capture using `shell_output_error` in commands, the dynamic log container, and the updated command execution via `shell_execute_line`. Iâ€™m also noting the fresh video/ATK widgets, keyboard handling improvements, the desktop icon for launching the shell, and CLI prompt tweaks, while referring to relevant source files and build verification steps.

payload.message:
- Added buffered shell output so commands can return reusable strings: the new helpers in `include/shell.h:10-37` and `src/sbin/shell.c:33-204` let handlers write into either a VFS target or a heap buffer, `shell_execute_line` now parses/executes commands into that buffer (`src/sbin/shell.c:237-371`), and the prompt writes the captured text back to the console (`src/sbin/shell.c:388-434`). Command implementations now report errors through the shared helper instead of touching the console directly (e.g., `src/sbin/cmd_cat.c:5-27`, `src/sbin/cmd_mkdir.c:5-15`, `src/sbin/cmd_start_video.c:9-31`).

- Introduced reusable ATK widgets and list plumbing to build dynamic UIs: label/text-input components live in `include/atk/atk_label.h:1-10`, `src/atk/atk_label.c:1-214`, `include/atk/atk_text_input.h:1-26`, and `src/atk/atk_text_input.c:1-212`, backed by the new list utility (`include/atk/atk_list.h:1-33`, `src/atk/atk_list.c:1-152`). Windows track buttons, text inputs, and child widgets via those lists and expose context hooks (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:35-88`, `src/atk/atk_window.c:167-371`, `src/atk/atk_window.h:6-16`), with `atk_handle_mouse_event` wiring focus and clicks into the new input widgets (`src/atk/atk.c:25-218`).

- Built an ATK shell app on top of those widgets: `src/atk/atk_shell.c:26-154` creates a window with a scrolling label and text input, dispatches user submissions through `shell_execute_line`, and appends both prompt and command output. A desktop icon now launches it (`src/atk/atk.c:34-55`, `src/atk/atk.c:356-364`). Keyboard flow is integrated by widening the public API (`include/atk.h:6-22`), adding state focus bookkeeping (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:60-82`), and polling the keyboard inside the video loop (`src/drivers/video.c:464-531`) so typing updates ATK via `atk_handle_key_char` (`src/atk/atk.c:332-354`).

- Rebuilt the text shell on top of the same execution path: it now calls `shell_run_and_display` and prints the shared buffer, using the standard `alex@alix$ ` prompt (`src/sbin/shell.c:205-434`).

- Verified the entire image builds with `make`.

content.text:
- Added buffered shell output so commands can return reusable strings: the new helpers in `include/shell.h:10-37` and `src/sbin/shell.c:33-204` let handlers write into either a VFS target or a heap buffer, `shell_execute_line` now parses/executes commands into that buffer (`src/sbin/shell.c:237-371`), and the prompt writes the captured text back to the console (`src/sbin/shell.c:388-434`). Command implementations now report errors through the shared helper instead of touching the console directly (e.g., `src/sbin/cmd_cat.c:5-27`, `src/sbin/cmd_mkdir.c:5-15`, `src/sbin/cmd_start_video.c:9-31`).

- Introduced reusable ATK widgets and list plumbing to build dynamic UIs: label/text-input components live in `include/atk/atk_label.h:1-10`, `src/atk/atk_label.c:1-214`, `include/atk/atk_text_input.h:1-26`, and `src/atk/atk_text_input.c:1-212`, backed by the new list utility (`include/atk/atk_list.h:1-33`, `src/atk/atk_list.c:1-152`). Windows track buttons, text inputs, and child widgets via those lists and expose context hooks (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:35-88`, `src/atk/atk_window.c:167-371`, `src/atk/atk_window.h:6-16`), with `atk_handle_mouse_event` wiring focus and clicks into the new input widgets (`src/atk/atk.c:25-218`).

- Built an ATK shell app on top of those widgets: `src/atk/atk_shell.c:26-154` creates a window with a scrolling label and text input, dispatches user submissions through `shell_execute_line`, and appends both prompt and command output. A desktop icon now launches it (`src/atk/atk.c:34-55`, `src/atk/atk.c:356-364`). Keyboard flow is integrated by widening the public API (`include/atk.h:6-22`), adding state focus bookkeeping (`src/atk/atk_internal.h:60-82`), and polling the keyboard inside the video loop (`src/drivers/video.c:464-531`) so typing updates ATK via `atk_handle_key_char` (`src/atk/atk.c:332-354`).

- Rebuilt the text shell on top of the same execution path: it now calls `shell_run_and_display` and prints the shared buffer, using the standard `alex@alix$ ` prompt (`src/sbin/shell.c:205-434`).

- Verified the entire image builds with `make`.
